linked.title: Welcome to the team
linked.body:
We‚Äôre excited that you‚Äôve joined Beyond Gravity. Welcome. Our mission is simple: get humanity off the ground and move technology forward by exploring the universe around us.
On your first day, you‚Äôll get to know all the details of our business goals and outlook. You‚Äôll settle into your new home (or pod!) and start learning how to contribute to what we think is the most important frontier.
This wiki contains all the information you‚Äôll need to get started on the team. And, we look forward to seeing where we go, together.

linked.title: T-45 requirements and component list
linked.body:
Follow the links for more information about components and specifications. Requirements older than 6 months should be considered a ‚Äúno go‚Äù. It‚Äôs up to each of us to follow up on outdated documentation. If you see something, say something!
The fourth generation T-45 rocket, associated modules, and launch systems are frozen. Additional scope and defect prevention will be evaluated by Jen on a per request basis. You can ping her on Stride or send a request in our Program Management service desk.

linked.title: Defects and fails - what to do when you smell something funny
linked.body:
Small failures add up. To prevent us from losing pace and pushing back milestones, be proactive with us. We can prevent death by a thousand paper cuts, if we all chip in.
Don‚Äôt be afraid to speak up if your estimates are off, if your component is failing, if your builds are red, if your head is a little out of sorts.
Here‚Äôs our defect process in a nutshell:
When you identify a defect, check the priority matrix to see how seriously it needs to be addressed.
If your defect is a blocker for deployment or readjusts the coordinated schedule, raise a ticket in your respective project and notify the program management group.
Assign yourself as the major point of contact.
Prepare a defect summary for the program management group.
Take a short break and remember that we‚Äôre in this together. Defects aren‚Äôt your fault!

linked.title: 2019-01-11 Meeting notes - Acceleration systems discussion
linked.body:
Date
  11 Jan 2019
Participants
  ‚Ä¢ @Sam Irons
  ‚Ä¢ @Jen Rubin
  ‚Ä¢ @James Rotanson
  ‚Ä¢ @Alicia Castaneda
Goals
  ‚Ä¢ Figure out milestones for delivering the new accelerator system to the T-45 rocket.
  ‚Ä¢ Work out what is missing to complete requirements documentation.
  ‚Ä¢ Break down ownership per component in the accelerator.
  ‚Ä¢ Have some cake for Jen‚Äôs birthday.
Discussion topics
Item: Happy birthday, Jen!
Time: 10min
Presenter: All
Notes: Cake contains nuts.
 
Item: Recap of specced accelerator components
Time: 15min
Presenter: Alicia
Notes: 5 components haven‚Äôt been estimated. Engineering will have proper estimates next week.
 
Item: Milestone discussion
Time: 30min
Presenter: Alicia
Notes: Some components can be developed asynchronously. 3 approaches identified. We‚Äôll open to the team for finding the best path forward.

linked.title: The "incident" üò±
linked.body:
I just want to remind everyone that it‚Äôs officially been 365 days since ‚Äúthe incident‚Äù. That‚Äôs 365 days without another ‚Äúincident‚Äù.
Fingers crossed, we all learned something that day. We all learned that ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà can ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà without much ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà to slow them down. After ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà, I‚Äôm fairly certain that ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ran aground on the launch site and ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà learned to pick up the slack.
But, mostly, I think we all learned a little about ourselves.
For reasons that should be obvious (see ‚ÄúDecision: We never speak of the incident again‚Äù), much of this blog post has been redacted.
If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôll be looking forward to another 365 days without another ‚Äúincident‚Äù. We hope.

linked.title: Elon's at it again
linked.body:
Like you‚Äôre not watching the latest Space X launch. If you haven‚Äôt, check it out. Elon‚Äôs at it again.
I think it‚Äôs important that we remember that Space X isn‚Äôt really much competition for us. They‚Äôre focused on privatized launches with minimal cargo load. We‚Äôre thinking lightyears ahead of them. (Get it? Light years‚Ä¶)
At any rate, James is preparing a response to Elon‚Äôs comments as we speak. And our launch is looking bigger and more exciting!
Check out the tweeters to see what I mean
